articles.title: Dynamic Social Vulnerability Index
articles.description: Understanding the Dynamic Social Vulnerability Index and its implications for human mobility and resilience.
articles.contents:
Dynamic Social Vulnerability Index (DSVI)
The Dynamic Social Vulnerability Index (DSVI) is a comprehensive metric designed to assess and quantify the social vulnerability of populations in a changing environment. Unlike static vulnerability indices, the DSVI incorporates temporal dynamics, recognizing that vulnerability is not fixed but evolves over time due to various socio-economic, environmental, and political factors.
Key Components
The DSVI typically includes several dimensions:
Socioeconomic Factors: Income levels, education, employment status, and access to resources.
Demographic Characteristics: Age, gender, ethnicity, and population density.
Health and Well-being: Access to healthcare, prevalence of chronic illnesses, and mental health indicators.
Infrastructure and Connectivity: Transportation networks, communication systems, and utility access.
Environmental Exposure: Proximity to hazards, climate change impacts, and natural disaster risks.
Applications in Mobility Science
In the context of human mobility, the DSVI helps in understanding how vulnerable populations respond to disruptions. For instance:
During natural disasters, areas with high DSVI may experience prolonged recovery times.
Migration patterns can be influenced by changing vulnerability levels in origin and destination regions.
Policy interventions can be targeted to reduce dynamic vulnerabilities over time.
Methodology
The DSVI is calculated using a combination of geospatial data, time-series analysis, and machine learning techniques to model vulnerability trajectories. It often integrates data from censuses, satellite imagery, and real-time sensors.
For more detailed research and data, refer to ongoing studies in social vulnerability and mobility science.
Interactive DSVI State Explorer
Explore the interactive DSVI state explorer: https://ogilani.shinyapps.io/dsvi/

articles.title: mobility.science
articles.contents: Human mobility describes physical patterns of movement of people within a spatial system. Many of these patterns, including daily commuting, are cyclic and quantifiable. These patterns capture physical phenomena tied to processes studied in epidemiology, and other social, behavioral, and economic sciences. This site captures and documents advancements in this area with emphasis on statistical and computational methods and tools.
